title: Broad Chalke Walks

images.title: Watercress beds, Broad Chalke by Maigheach-gheal, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Watercress beds, Broad Chalke. You can find this pretty area on the western side of the village.

images.title: River Ebble, Broad Chalke - (5) by Maigheach-gheal, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Ebble

images.title: Ronald Searle / A Quiet Corner - Broad Chalke
images.caption: A Quiet Corner - Broad Chalke. Looking north towards South Street and the C15 entrance to Kings Old Rectory, before the installation of wooden gates. The larger of the two Tudor arches was intended for carts, whilst the smaller entry was for pedestrians.

images.title: Mike Searle / All Saints Church - Broad Chalke
images.caption: All Saints Church. The parish church of All Saints is a Grade I listed building. It dates from the late 13th and 14th centuries and includes a 15th-century porch.

images.title: Mike Searle / Kings Old Rectory - Broad Chalke
images.caption: Kings Old Rectory. The south front of Kings Old Rectory, a Grade II* Listed C15 detached house, with C16 and C17 additions at the rear. This is a former rectory owned by Kings College, Cambridge till 1923.

images.title: Bridleway, Broad Chalke by Maigheach-gheal, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridleway

images.title: River Ebble, Broad Chalke by Maigheach-gheal, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Ebble - cattle in the river

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / The Queens Head, Broad Chalke, Wiltshire
images.caption: The Queens Head, Broad Chalke, Wiltshire

description: This picturesque Wiltshire based village is a lovely place for an easy stroll. There's some pleasant countryside trails and views of the River Ebble which meanders through the village. Broad Chalke is located in the Cranborne Chase AONB, a few miles south west of the famous cathedral city of Salisbury . This circular walk explores the settlement visiting the watercress beds, the 15th century Kings Old Rectory and the ancient parish church before heading into the surrounding countryside on the local public footpaths and bridleways. To continue your walking in the area head south to visit Martin Down Nature Reserve where there's hundreds of acres of chalk download with wildflower meadows and lots of wildlife to see.
